Nikolai, the idea of having a gene encapsulate a number of components is si=
milar to the idea in Modular NEAT from Joeseph Reisinger a few years ago: 
=

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco04

However, I believe that=
 this idea is not the best direction for encoding modules (and I believe Jo=
e Reisinger would agree).  The problem is that once you encapsulate several=
 genes into one gene, it becomes too easy to repeat that module all over th=
e place, which runs a high risk of putting it in places it does not belong.=
  Most large complex modules do not easily fit literally anywhere.

A bette=
r approach is through indirect encoding, like in HyperNEAT, which tends to =
elaborate on preexisting regularities to create additional complexity.  So =
I think HyperNEAT is a more promising direction for encoding regularities o=
r repeating substructures than a system that tries to create an explicit hi=
erarchy.

ken

rote:

etups with

> have you guy=
s considered for NEAT v2 a gene to be not just a link, but a group of links=
 ? And even more, a gene to be a well defined large network ? I have found =
this video called "inner life of a cell", amazing video btw:
> http://www.s=
tudiodaily.com/main/searchlist/6850.html
> for example, check the motor pro=
tein walking on the video and carrying a sphere of lipids, that gene has on=
ly one function of "moving stuff". Could next version of NEAT evolve someth=
ing like that and separate it as a net and name it as some sort of "complex=
 gene", for later reuse to build more complex structures? For example, it w=
ould scan through whole population, and recognize inside each network, a sm=
all subnetwork that is repeating along many species, then it would disconne=
ct this network, and name it as a gene. Do you think it could work ?
>

hanks for your comments.
> Nikolai
